fields.description:
Based on our recent findings if you expire build artifacts and logs only but keep build results (tests etc) for reporting purposes after 4 months of uptime a backup takes more then 4 hours on a 2 core machine with 8GB RAM.

We should be able to expire in this case the build results after 2-3 months to be able to run backups during night.
fields.summary: While expire build artifact/logs has it's reason, expire build results should be allowed on a different schedule

fields.description: No skipped TestNG test results are being reported in the Tests tab.
fields.summary: Skipped test results are not being reported

fields.description:
Depending on the resulting state of the Job, having a trinary switch "Always Execute/Execute on Success/Execute on Failure" on the Final tasks would be useful. For instance, I might want to always run an external tool to clean up data, but insert different information into a reporting tool depending on success or failure; technically, the success flag isn't required since I could just make it the last task in the job, but it seems like the extra effort might be worth it to avoid confusion when reading through the job.

Just a thought.
fields.summary: Would be nice to be able to differentiate final tasks on Bamboo jobs by ifSuccessful/ifFailed

fields.description:
I have 2 repositories, R1 and R2 - and according plans P1 and P2. 
P2 depends on P1 (parent-child).

#1
When I push a change to R1 plan P1 is triggered and built.

#2
When I push a change to R2 plan P2 is triggered and built.

#3
When I push changes to R1 AND R2, P1 as well as P2 are triggered and built.
BUT the problem is that when P1 fails, P2 is built anyway.

This makes no sense. The expected behaviour would be to mark P2 failed/skipped because of failed dependencies. Otherwise it's just a waste of resources.
fields.summary: Don't build plan if parent failed

fields.description: In the artifact definition page, the list of artifacts sorted by names are first done or grouped based on shared or unshared. It will be nice if this is done strictly based on alphabetical order. For example I have three unshared artifacts a,b & d and a shared artifact c. Naturally, it should be sorted in the order a,b,c,d but this is rather done as a,b,d,c. See screenshot
fields.summary: Artifacts list name sort should be strictly alphabetical not based on groupings

fields.description:
When adding a Source Repository of type GitHub, you're able to enter the credentials for a GitHub account and click Load Repositories to fetch the repo list from GitHub. However, if the account in question has more than 30 repos, only the newest 30 are shown in the Bamboo drop-down.

I'm guessing the cause is that the GitHub repo list API is paginated to 30-at-a-time, and Bamboo is only fetching the first page of results.

fields.description:
When you go to the UPM page and you have Bamboo proxied you get the error:
bq. The base URL configuration of your instance is inconsistent with the URL in your browser. This may prevent many operations on this page from working correctly. See the UPM documentation for more details about this error.

Tomcat connectors have proxyhost and proxyport config which tell the app that a proxy is involved. JIRA/Confluence use this to check for proxy (See [KB|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/False+Warning+About+Server+Base+URL+Mismatches+on+UPM]).

We need to provide some sort of mechanism to let users configure their proxyhost/proxyport in Bamboo.
AFAIK - we'll need to implement a custom connector.

P.S. Fisheye which uses Jetty has a similar feature using custom connector.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# configure a plan that might run for some time
# make a commit by UserA that triggers a build
# while the previous build is still running, make another commit by UserB that would trigger a second build run after the previous one is done
# go to the project page that shows the plan, it should still shows reason as "Changes by UserA" (see [^bam13046-0-before-change.jpg])
# do not manually refresh the browser, just wait for bamboo to auto-refresh the plan status to indicate the previous build is done and the second build is triggered

Expected
# reason is changed to "Changes by UserB"
# when mouse over the reason, it shows details about the changes "Who: UserB, Why: xxx"

Actual
# reason is changed to "Changes by UserB" (correct)
# when mouse over the reason, it shows details about the first commit "Who: UserA, Why: yyy" (see [^bam13046-1-after-change.jpg])
fields.summary: Tooltip shows previous change reason after auto-refresh

fields.description:
Dragging a stage up or down in my list of plan stages gives this error:

Stage move failed
Failed to move Stage, the provided Stage (PurgeExpiredBuilds) is not currently part of the Plan (NAMOB-TCANDV0102RL)

The stage is properly moved, may or may not reflect its new location on the web page, but reloading page always shows that the move succeeded.

This occurs in Bamboo version 4.4.4, which I can't select in the "Affects Version/s" dropdown on this site. I chose 4.4.3 instead, but I don't really know if the bug exists there.

fields.description:
When getting build results using the REST API I can't use multiple expand parameters.

Example (works)
/builds/rest/api/latest/result?label=productiondeploy&buildstate=successful&expand=results.result.comments.comment

Example (works)
/builds/rest/api/latest/result?label=productiondeploy&buildstate=successful&expand=results.result.jiraIssues

Example (does not work)
/builds/rest/api/latest/result?label=productiondeploy&buildstate=successful&expand=results.result.comments.comment,results.result.jiraIssues

In the example that does not work only jiraIssues are expanded. Comments does not expand.

IMHO the problem is the implementation of DefaultExpandParameter.parse which always put's new item to the parameters map without checking if something is there already.
fields.summary: Problem with multiple expand parameters

fields.description:
If a job fails it would be nice for JIRA to be able to rerun the failed jobs as part of the retry release workflow.

Rerunning the failed jobs in Bamboo directly does not result in the release being successful.

The work around we found is to go into Admin mode and release the version from there, this leaves the build information in the release.
fields.summary: Allow "Rerun failed jobs" for failed release build

fields.description:
Gatekeeper automatically merges master to a branch before kicking off the build. But if someone makes a commit on master before the Gatekeeper build finishes, Gatekeeper will be unable to push at the end. This is already filed as BAM-11007 and BAM-12146.

Those bugs propose serializing Gatekeeper builds, so no two builds may run simultaneously. But that's not good enough if people are allowed to push commits to master directly, as they are at our company.

Instead, we'd like for Gatekeeper to automatically do a second merge _after_ the build is done, and push that. The resulting pushed branch wouldn't be guaranteed to build safely, but we're willing to take that risk if it allows us to run concurrent Gatekeeper builds. (We only wanted Gatekeeper to protect against blatant build breakages, not to protect against merge conflicts per se.)
fields.summary: Gatekeeper should optionally automatically merge *after* build as well

fields.description:
I tried to delete artifacts for a build and noticed that it is not working. I tested this on both 4.4.0 and 4.4.4. If I click on the Default Job, I am able to successfully delete the artifact with the "Remove Job Artifact" Button but the "Remove Artifacts" button at the build level doesn't do any thing. It doesn't remove the artifact from Bamboo or from the stored location on disk.

Attached screenshots are showing the process (Follow the 1 to 5 numbers for the right order)
fields.summary: Remove Build Artifacts is not working

fields.description:
Build results can consume quite a bit of disk space (23GB in one case).  We should probably enable some kind of reasonable expiration: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Enabling+Expiry+of+Build+Results

We should also inform customers if we enable this in the future.
fields.summary: Ship Bamboo with Build Result Expiration settings

fields.description:
The Bamboo UI prompts for Project, Plan and Job keys but once this information is entered and saved, it cannot be easily accessed. 

* I understand the need to simplify the UI (BAM-8109)
* I agree that Project/Plan/Job names are more descriptive than the associated keys.
* I understand that these keys are visible in various Bamboo URLs. However, this does not provide adequate visibility and the URLs are not something I consider to be part of the GUI. The URL is a browser interface not user interface.

Given the current design direction to use the names exclusively in the GUI, how can I:
* See a list of keys for Projects and Plans?
* Choose well named keys for new projects/plans if I cannot see any prior keys?
* Given a directory in bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/* determine the human readable project and plan names?
* Implement a Project/Plan/Job naming convention?

It seems to me that the Bamboo user interface needs to expose these keys so they are visible somewhere in the UI. For example, In the Dashboard, there are the tabs: My Bamboo, All Plans, Current Activity. The All Plans tab targets watching over builds and build status of all projects/plans. Would it make sense to add a "Plan Info" or such tab that listed the Project key, Plan key in addition to the names? This tab would not list build/completed/tests/reason columns.

A Plan Info type dashboard could show information like
* The last time the plan was modified
* The Project, Plan keys
* The number of stages/jobs in the plan (with drill down to see the stages and job keys)
* A link to an audit log showing the edit history of the plan
* The path to the plan's build directory
etc.
fields.summary: Project, Plan, Job keys are inaccessible from UI

fields.description:
I was able to reproduce the error that happens when trying to re-order stages in Bamboo. The error happens even when the stage contains a job.

Have a look at the attached screenshots.
fields.summary: Re-ordering stages results in "Stage not part of plan" error

fields.description:
The Bamboo plan creation process is confusing. While it simplifies the process of creating the first plan/stage/job, it does not orient the user the notion of stages and creates default names for the first stage & job created.

Attachments include:

Picture 1

    First job getting created.
    Nowhere on this screen is the word "stage" mentioned.
    The user is not given the opportunity to name the stage or the job.

Picture 2

    The default names for the first stage and job are shown.
    The user has to assume that these names were created by Bamboo during the creation process.
    Creating subsequent plans is a pain because every plan will have these default names for the first stage/job if the plans are not cloned.
fields.summary: Plan creation process does not allow user to name first Stage & Job

fields.description:
When a plan is deleted it isn't removed from Bamboo.
The plan is marked for deletion and doesn't appear in the UI.

If a customer re-creates the plan with same Plan Key, then he gets an error saying the plan key already exists - we should throw a more meaningful error.
fields.summary: False error when re-creating a deleted plan

There is a workaround
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Authentication+Failure+with+NTLM+Subversion+Authentication

If we use the workaround by default all the time (This is done by Fisheye and many of our competitors) and if users want to force NTLM they can do this via a checkbox in the UI.

fields.description:
Request form customer 
{quote}
I'm evaluating Bamboo have one question regarding the Error Log display for Tests.
Currently, it appears that all the text is "escaped". Meaning any html markup that is in my error log is being displayed as tags in the error log instead of rendered html. 

My error logs come from DevExpress' EasyTest system and contain references to screen snapshot image files and saved html pages on each test case failure. I've created a simple xsl that converts the EasyTest xml to JUnit compatible format so it is parsing my output fine and I stuff all the links to the images and other resources in the JUnit xml's failure node (which shows in bamboo as escaped text). 

But I want to have images and hyperlinks in my error log render as html in bamboo so I can see the images and click on the hyperlinks to other error resources. Otherwise, all these extra images and files that were output on test failure are burried in directories on the server.

{quote}
fields.summary: Bamboo displays marked-up text as plain links when viewing tests

fields.description:
Create a new plan and configure Gatekeeper with push enabled. Use a regex for automatic plan branching, e.g. /gatekeeper-/ so only branches containing "gatekeeper-" will be automatically created and set up with Gatekeeper.

Now, create a VCS branch whose name doesn't contain gatekeeper- e.g. "dangerous-do-not-merge." Go to the plan's branches page and click "Create Branch," select your branch, and click "Create."

On the branch configuration UI, you'll now have the option to set branch settings, e.g. to set up Branch Updater, or disable push, or even disable the branch build altogether while you configure other settings.

Actual: While you're reading that page, Bamboo will automatically kick off a Gatekeeper build of dangerous-do-not-merge, with push enabled. You have to quickly go in and kill the build before it commits those changes to the master branch.

Expected: An "Enable Branch" checkbox on the default "Create Branch" dialog. 

Today, the Create Branch dialog has two modes, one to "Auto-detect VCS branches" (which is different from automatic plan branching; it's just auto-detecting and listing branches for you to manually create) and another to "Create branch manually." There's an "Enable Branch" checkbox in the "Create branch manually" mode, unchecked by default, but there isn't a corresponding checkbox in the "Auto-detect VCS branches" list mode. (Screenshots attached.)

That means that it's dangerous to use the "Auto-detect VCS branches" mode (the default) together with automatic plan branching and branch merging, because if you use it, it's going to immediately start checking in code unless you kill the build.
fields.summary: Bamboo immediately begins Gatekeepering/pushing manually-created branches

fields.description:
1) Define a shared SVN repository through the Bamboo administration section. Set the repository to use "SVN Export".

2) Create a new plan.

3) In the plan's "Repositories" section, attach the shared repository.

4) Go back to the dashboard. Select the plan, select the repositories tab, and view the repository you associated in step (3).

The "SVN Export" field appears twice.
fields.summary: When viewing a plan's repository, and the repository is shared, the "SVN Export" field appears twice

fields.description:
Currently, when viewing the repositories of a plan, initially no repository is selected for viewing. It might actually make more sense to automatically select a repository:

1) If there is only one repository defined, it should be automatically selected. There is no reason why not to.

2) If there is more than one repository, then the first one should be automatically selected.
fields.summary: When viewing plan's repositories and only one repository exists, it should be automatically selected

fields.description:
Scenario:

r20----
----New Stage xyz: Report Dir r20

We checkout a revision and begin to build it (Rev. 20). At the moment of building New Stage xyz a trigger get's pulled for example that runs a new build and the revision that we get will now be r21 instead of r20.

What we want to receive as the revision number at this stage is 20.
fields.summary: Retrieve the original SVN Branch Revision Number (before pulled trigger or a simultaneous checked revision)

fields.description:
The automatic build labeling doesn't appear to be working. For each job in my plan, I label it via [the job] > Miscellaneous tab (see screenshot). Based on the documentation, I should be able to label ALL builds if I simply leave the "Regex Pattern" field blank. Once the build completes however, the build results page doesn't show any labels being applied to the build (see other screenshot). Below is the Bamboo Version I am running. If that field doesn't work the way I'm expecting it to work (i.e. it functions as designed), please inform me what I'm doing wrong.

I'm following the documentation found here:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+automatic+labelling+of+job+build+results

Bamboo Version Information
Version 4.4.1
Build Number 3502
Build Date 2/5/13
fields.summary: Automatic job labeling not working

fields.description:
We just upgraded Bamboo to the latest version (4.4.4) and found out that there was a feature that we have long been taking for granted, and now it's gone. When running a plan customized (overriding plan variables) we used to be able to see all the variables (and their values) all listed out. Now, you have to select a variable from a drop-down list. While this may seem like an insignificant change, it is actually affecting our users quite a bit. Now, instead of being able to see at a glance what variables are okay and which ones need to be overridden, they are forced to either remember which variables need to be changed for each and every plan, or they have to do a long series of clicking to bring out every variable in the drop-down list so they can get back to how things were and see what needs to be changed. It would be great if you could just include like a "Run Customized View Preference" option where you could specify specific plan variables that should be shown every time.

I hope that all made sense, let me know if you have any questions.
fields.summary: Run Customized - Plan Variable View Preferences

fields.description:
currently the Build expiry functionality only allows to filter with Labels

BUT if you start a release Build from JIRA, the build doesn't get a labe, so if you forget to label it manually the _release_ build gets deleted (!)

There are several solution for this:
* Jira labels its Bamboo builds
* the Buildexpiry task is extended with the possibilty to filter also for buildname
* Bamboo provides some automatic label functionality (built in, not through add on)

more details can be found [her|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/144871/automatic-build-expiry-configuration?page=1#comment-147472]

fields.description:
We are using plan branches extensively and also quarantining of tests. We are finding that when a new plan branch is created automatically by Bamboo (as per regex) the quarantined test list is not inherited from the master branch.

The main build has 15 quarantined tests but new branches seem to start off with 8 quarantined tests.

Steps to reproduce:
* create plan with 2 jobs
* quarantine tests in both jobs
* create plan branch
* run build

Expected: quarantined tests were inherited
Actual: only tests from first job were inherited
fields.summary: Plan branch does not inherit quarantined tests

fields.description:
The problem was previously described here https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/136454/get-set-plan-variables
VariableDefinitionManager.getPlanVariables for PlanManager.getPlanByKey (with a key from TaskContext.BuildContext.PlanResultKey.PlanKey inside a task plugin) returns a VariableDefinition list disjoint from Plan/Customizable variables.  With VariableDefinitionFactory, its createPlanVariable method allows to populate that hidden list, which persists between restarts.    And it does not allow to add more customizable variables.  Both lists contribute to ExternalProcess context.

Adding a label to the build result with LabelManager also adds it to the Job Result rather than to the Plan Result.  This label is hidden, it only appears in the select-by-label results.

EDIT: Przemek Bruski's answer at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/65019/bamboo-apis-iterate-all-stages-and-jobs-on-a-plan hinted that a single PlanKey may identify multiple plans and I discovered PlanKeys API and how to get a real plan from the one returned by getPlanByKey.  So maybe this issue is of a missing and outdated documentation kind.
fields.summary: DefaultJob has its own invisible Plan variables and Plan Result labels

fields.description:
In our Bamboo environment, we have over 100 actively used plans. Each of those plans checks out code from Subversion. When entering authentication credentials for the repository in the plans initial configuration stage, we use an Active Directory account that was created specifically for Bamboo (we call it a BPID, Business Process ID) instead of having the developers authenticate using their own credentials. We do this so that the repository settings do not need to be updated every time a developer leaves the company or changes his/her password. However, there are several problems with this approach. First of all, the BPID credentials are supposed to be private (not written down on a sticky note on every developers desk). Second, the BPID password is supposed to be changed every 90 days (which is nearly impossible, seeing as how it would require going into each and every one of our 100+ plans and updating the source code repository settings). I was somewhat hopeful that the new "Shared Repository" feature would solve this issue, but while it does save the authentication credentials and store them centrally, it only allows us to save one specific repository URL and does not allow for plan-specific modifications to that URL.

What I'm looking for is a way to allow all plans to specify their individual repository URLs while not having to worry about the authentication credentials. There needs to be a way to have some sort of root-level configuration in the Administration tab that allows me to say "Here's my base-level repository URL, and here are the credentials to use" and then that would let me reconfigure the individual plans to use that base-level URL and then tack on their plan-specific URL on to that one. The developer would never have to worry about the authentication piece. But then I would have the ability to keep my BPID private and I could also go to that setting in the Administration tab once every 90 days and update the password in one place and one place only.

Is this just wishful thinking, or do you think it can be done? And do you know of any workaround that I could use in the meantime? I'm using version 4.4.4.
fields.summary: Centralized credential management

Would have loved it if build history was imported as well.
A good experience over all.

fields.description:
With atlassian-bamboo-* 4.4.0 or 4.4.4 and atlassian-user 1.9.1, com.atlassian.bamboo.comment.CommentManagerImpl.addComment invokes getName on a com.atlassian.user.User-interface instance, but User does not declare this method.

I see that com.atlassian.user.impl.DefaultUser provides this method, but by its name it is not supposed to be instantiated from the external code, and indeed addComment fails with it with net.sf.hibernate.LazyInitializationException.

Should I use some other way to add a comment from a plugin?  If not, how can I get a User instance for this method?
fields.summary: comment.CommentManagerImpl.addComment invokes a User method not declared in its interface

fields.description: In some cases, we need to maintain a code for more than one MacOS/iOS release version. Since Xcode may differ between OS revisions, support more than one Xcode installations could be very helpful, avoiding to run more than one plan, one per OS release.
fields.summary: Support for more than one Xcode installation on the same instance of Bamboo remote agent.

fields.description:
After Installing Stash 2.2.0 I configured a Bamboo 4.4.4 plan to use Stash as a source repository, and I noticed the following on the command line window:
{code}
Armens-MacBook-Pro:~ akhachatryan$ /Users/akhachatryan/Atlassian/Bamboo4.4.4/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.4/bamboo.sh start
Starting Bamboo: 
STARTED Bamboo Fri Mar  8 17:04:57 PST 2013
Bamboo running, pid=16320
Armens-MacBook-Pro:~ akhachatryan$ Username: 
Password: 
Username: 
Password: 
Username: 
Password: 
Username: 
Password: 
Username: 
Password: 
Username: 
Password: 
Username: 
Password: 
{code}

The plan fails to check out from the Stash repo, and I see systems errros:
{code}
Plan 'PROJ1-PLAN1' could not be started. Exception: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Runtime exception.
(java.lang.RuntimeException : com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Runtime exception.) 
{code}
fields.summary: Bamboo pops up username password request from command line when trying to use Stash as source repository

fields.description:
I was able to reproduce the problem:
{code}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: cannot save merged build definitions
	at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkArgument(Preconditions.java:88)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plan.PlanHibernateDao.save(PlanHibernateDao.java:428)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plan.PlanHibernateDao.save(PlanHibernateDao.java:45)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:304)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:182)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:149)
	at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:106)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)
{code}
by following these steps:

1. Pick any plan first.

2. Go to the configuration.

3. Under Branches, click “Create Branch”.

4. Give a Branch Display Name, enable, and create.

5. Go to the Stages & Jobs, pick any job to test the change update.

6. When the job is disable originally, check the “Job Enabled” checkbox and save. The error page appears

7. When the job is enable originally, uncheck the “Job Enable” checkbox and save. The error page appears
fields.summary: After creating a Branch plan, Editing Job Details page fails

fields.description:
In BuildTask interface : http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/latest/com/atlassian/bamboo/v2/build/task/BuildTask.html

The description reads "Interface the defines a basic interface..."

Seems like it should be "Interface that defines a basic interface..."
fields.summary: Minor Typo in Javadoc for BuildTask interface

fields.description: I know this is pretty trivial, but when I "Clone an existing plan" it would be nice if the sort order of the dropdown for "Plan to clone" was the same as the sort order used in the dashboard. It would make things a bit easier to find (and keep track of when cloning a bunch of plans in order). It seems that the dashboard sorts case-insensitive, but the "plan to clone" dropdown sorts with case sensitivity. Consistency would be nice. thank you for considering this.
fields.summary: "plan to clone" sort order different than dashboard

fields.description:
currently the default Time Format Bamboo is 12h with AM/PM
but in the more civilized :P world a 24H format is used.

Currently changing the format is only possible by editing some properties fils
See [Change DateTime Format|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/35820/change-the-date-time-format-to-24h]

A simple entry on the userinterface like in [Jira|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Customising+the+Look+and+Feel] would be nice
fields.summary: Allow setting of Date/Time Format from Webfrontend
